I obviously have a bunch of thoughts on it, but I want to hear yours, which are if the general thesis 45 days manage about 21. Once we get within 21, a lot of these other things come out of the woodwork. Their question was, well, then why isn't it at 21? Why don't you just inverse take the other side? It's a fair question. But that's what I thought. But it's an easy answer. Exactly. It's not because the odds change at 21 days. It has nothing to do with that. It's the magnitude of the change in the decay curve where you end up taking so much more risk. So what that means is the reason you don't flip the cards over is if you put a trade on it 45 days and you let it go, let's just say as an example, and you let it go to expiration. And let's say your chance of success is 65. Then in the end, if you do enough time, it's going to be 65. If you

metadata.title: Tales of a Trader with Tom Sosnoff | The Outlier Podcast Ep72

text: put a trade on it 45 days and you let it go, let's just say as an example, and you let it go to expiration. And let's say your chance of success is 65. Then in the end, if you do enough time, it's going to be 65. If you put the same trade on it 45 days and you take it off at 21 days, your probability of success is still going to be 65. So there's no difference. You're 65.
